technical-data.invention-title: VERBUNDMATERIALSTRUKTUR MIT EINER EINGEBETTETEN OPTISCHEN FASER IN EINER SEINER OBERFLÄCHENSCHICHTEN UND VERBINDUNGS- UND REPARATURVERFAHREN DAFÜR
COMPOSITE MATERIAL STRUCTURE HAVING AN EMBEDDED OPTICAL FIBRE IN ONE OF THE SURFACE LAYERS THEREOF AND METHOD FOR CONNECTING AND REPAIRING THE SAME
STRUCTURE DE MATERIAU COMPOSITE POURVUE D'UNE FIBRE OPTIQUE INTEGREE DANS UNE DES SES COUCHES SUPERFICIELLES ET PROCEDE DE CONNEXION ET DE REPARATION AFFERENT

address.street: Airbus España, S.L. Avda. John Lennon s/n Getafe

description.p: The present invention relates to a composite structure incorporating embedded optical fiber for structural monitoring purposes, and more particularly to a composite structure of an aircraft, as well as a process for its connection and repair.

The intensive introduction of advanced composites in primary structures has become a fundamental process of structural optimization (based on weight savings and the improvement of mechanical properties), one of the top priorities in the design and manufacture of a new generation of aircrafts. The introduction of an effective structural monitoring system capable of predicting the failure of load paths in a structure designed according to damage tolerance criteria would allow optimizing its design and, accordingly, reducing its weight.

Optical fiber sensors can be effectively used to measure thermomechanical deformation and even to detect damage events operating both alone in passive structural monitoring systems and in combination with other devices, forming an active monitoring system. One of their main advantages is their capacity to be embedded in composite structures, being intimately integrated into the structures.

US 5309533 A discloses a composite material formed of a plurality of sheets forming plies, a casing formed between two of the plurality of sheets forming the composite material, the casing having an internal diameter, an optical fibre located within the casing and having an external diameter which is less than the internal diameter of the casing, the optical fibre also having a slow axis and a fast axis of propagation.

WO 2006/107278 A1 provides an optical fiber strain sensor with a composite structure, in which an aluminium caulplate is used as the base for the lay-up. The caulplate is wrapped with a layer of release fabric Teflon coated fiber glass or non-porous release film (Release Ease 234 TFNP) that has been cleaned with acetone to remove any contaminants that might affect the surface quality of the cured laminates before laying the carbon fiber prepregs. The composite laminate is prepared by layering prepregs onto the non-porous release film on the caulplate using a manual lay-up method. At this stage, the grating fiber containing the two fiber Bragg gratings is introduced in the prepregs with the grating fiber running parallel to the reinforced fiber of each. The completed laminate is covered with a layer of release fabric Teflon coated fiberglass or porous release film (Release Ease 234 TFNP), followed by a breather cloth (Airwaves Super) to absorb the excess resin. Finally, a layer of non-porous release film is placed on top of the breather cloth before the whole set-up is transferred to a composite-curing table (e.g. Heatcon 9500) or a vacuum oven (e.g. Salvis Lab Vacuum Oven Vacucenter VC-20).

However, one of the drawbacks of this integration is the difficulty that the integration of the optical fiber has under real laminate manufacturing conditions and the repair of these same fibers once they are embedded. Optical fiber has extremely small dimensions and due to its fragility, it is difficult to handle during the handling operations associated to the integration processes during the manufacture of the laminate, the manufacture of the vacuum bag and curing in the autoclave (or any other alternative laminate consolidation process), the connectorization and subsequent maintenance and/or repair operations of the same optical fiber of the housing laminate. In particular, the scarce possibilities of accessing the optical fiber once it is embedded are very slim and even slimmer yet with regard to its successful repair, which is incompatible with the reparability requirements needed when the structural health and maintenance criteria are bound to the correct working of the network of sensors integrated in the structure.
The present invention is aimed at solving this drawback.

In a first aspect, the present invention proposes a composite structure comprising:
a) a laminate structure formed by a plurality of layers;
b) an optical fiber for structural monitoring purposes which is at least partly embedded in said laminate structure, the embedded part of the optical fiber susceptible to requiring repair is integrated in a surface layer of the laminate structure; and
c) insulation means located at the optical fiber areas susceptible to repair with respect to the surface layer in which they are integrated; said insulation means including:
a bottom separating film positioned below the optical fiber between the optical fiber and the laminate structure so as to facilitate the separation of the optical fiber from the laminate structure,
a top separating film positioned on the optical fiber, and
a laminar protective cover arranged on the top separating film.

These insulation means protect the optical fiber during the structure manufacturing process and allow subsequent access thereto for its maintenance (connection, modification of the line or damage repair while in service) without significantly affecting the integrity of the structure.

In a second aspect the present invention proposes a process of repairing the optical fiber embedded in said composite structure comprising the following steps:
Removing the insulation means from the optical fiber area in need of repair.
Extracting the optical fiber area in need of repair from the composite structure.
Repairing the optical fiber.
Relocating the repaired optical fiber area in the composite structure.
Providing a new protective cover on the repaired optical fiber area.

The optical fiber integration techniques proposed in this invention allow embedding optical fiber in composite structures, assuring the continued existence of the former at the points of entry in the structure and allowing access to the fiber at these points of entry or at intermediate points for its maintenance (connection, modification of the line or damage repair while in service), all this without significantly affecting the structural integrity of the laminate.
Other features and advantages of the present invention will be understood from the following detailed description of an illustrative embodiment of its object in relation to the attached drawings.

description.p: Figure 1 shows a composite structure 11 known in the art formed by a plurality of layers 13, 15, 17, 19, 21, 23 with an optical fiber 25 embedded within it that can be part of both a sensor network and part of a data transmission element embedded within it. The integration of this fiber 25 in the structure 11 is a complex and delicate process, especially regarding the points of entry of the fiber 25 in said structure, required for its connection to the outside, and the continued existence of these points during the consolidation process.

Furthermore, if for any reason it were necessary to access said optical fiber 25 to proceed to the maintenance thereof (connection, modification of the line or damage repair while in service), it is possible to reach it by means of composite repair techniques consisting of the local removal of the reinforcement layers 13, 15 until accessing the fiber 25. However optical fiber 15 is a very fragile element and said operations for removing parts of the layers of the structure can damage it, as is shown in Figure 2.

According to the invention, the structure 11 includes insulation means of the optical fiber 25 insulating it from the layers in which it is embedded, increasing its possibilities of continued existence and facilitating access thereto at those points susceptible to having maintenance operations (connection, modification of the line or damage repair while in service) performed thereon.

Therefore, and as is shown in Figures 3-5, in the case of structures 11 with optical fiber 25 embedded in the surface layer 13, and at certain points such as the points of entry of the optical fiber 25 in the structure 11 through the surface, or at intermediate points chosen as suitable points for performing maintenance tasks, the following insulation means are incorporated:
A bottom separating film 33 between the structure and the optical fiber 25 which will facilitate the separation for the optical fiber from the laminate in order to perform maintenance tasks on it after the consolidation process for consolidating the layers of preimpregnated material to form the structure.
A top separating film 31, like the previous one preferably oriented in the direction of the reinforcement fibers, located on the optical fiber 25.
A laminar protective cover 27 having dimensions slightly larger than those of the separating films 31, 33.

The separating films 31, 33 are made of a material that is resistant to the temperature and pressure of the consolidation process, which is incompatible with the resin of the laminate, and the protective cover 27 is made of a preimpregnated fiberglass fabric or a similar material.
The optical fiber 25 cannot be completely embedded in the surface layer 13 as is shown in figure 4, it being sufficient that only those areas considered appropriate be embedded.
Figures 6-7 sequentially illustrate the fundamental steps of a first embodiment of the process of repairing optical fiber in structures herein described.

After removing the protective cover 27 and the top separating film 31, the optical fiber 25 that is embedded in the structure 11 but separated from it by the bottom separating film 33 is removed, and the optical fiber is repaired by means of, for example, joining by fusion 45 of the ends 41, 43 of the optical fiber 25 and the part removed from the structure is returned, remaining in the position shown in Figure 8.

Figures 8 and 9 show a second embodiment of the repair process which differs from the first one only in that the optical fiber 25 repair is carried out, for example, by means of joining by fusion 47 one of its ends 51 to the end 53 of an external optical fiber 55, reconducting the optical signal through an alternative path.

In both processes, the repair can include returning the separating films 31, 33 and the protective cover 27 by supplying a small amount of adhesive 29 on the top separating film 33 and applying a consolidation process that is common in repairing composite laminates.
In the preferred embodiment described above any modifications comprised within the scope defined by the following claims can be introduced.

claim.claim-text: Verbundstruktur (11), die Folgendes umfasst: a) eine Laminatstruktur, die durch mehrere Schichten (13, 15, 17, 19, 21, 23) gebildet wird; b) eine optische Faser (25) für den Zweck der strukturellen Überwachung, die mindestens teilweise in die Laminatstruktur eingebettet ist, wobei der eingebettete Teil der optischen Faser (25), der unter Umständen repariert werden muss, in eine Oberflächenschicht (13) der Laminatstruktur integriert ist; und c) Isoliermittel (31, 33, 27), die sich in den Bereichen der optischen Faser, die unter Umständen repariert werden müssen, mit Bezug auf die Oberflächenschicht (13), in die sie integriert sind, befinden, wobei die Isoliermittel (31, 33, 27) Folgendes enthalten: - einen unteren Trennfilm (33), der unter der optischen Faser (25) zwischen der optischen Faser (25) und der Laminatstruktur angeordnet ist, um die Trennung der optischen Faser (25) von der Laminatstruktur zu erleichtern, - einen oberen Trennfilm (31), der auf der optischen Faser (25) angeordnet ist, und - einen laminaren Schutzüberzug (27), der auf dem oberen Trennfilm (31) angeordnet ist.
Verbundstruktur nach Anspruch 1, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass die Abmessungen des Schutzüberzuges (27) geringfügig größer sind als jene der Trennfilme (31, 33).
Verbundstruktur nach Anspruch 1 oder 2, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass der Schutzüberzug (27) aus vorimprägniertem Glasfasergewebe besteht.
Verbundstruktur nach Anspruch 3, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass die gesamte optische Faser (25) in eine Oberflächenschicht (13) der Struktur (11) eingebettet ist.

Verbundstruktur nach Anspruch 3, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass der Teil der optischen Faser (25), der nicht in die Oberflächenschicht (13) der Struktur (11) eingebettet ist, in die Schicht (15) daneben oder tiefer eingebettet ist.

Prozess zum Reparieren der optischen Faser, die in eine Verbundstruktur nach den Ansprüchen 6 oder 7 eingebettet ist, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass der reparierte Bereich der optischen Faser (25) Enden (41, 43) der optischen Faser (25) verbindet, die in die Verbundstruktur eingebettet ist.

Prozess zum Reparieren der optischen Faser, die in eine Verbundstruktur nach den Ansprüchen 6 oder 7 eingebettet ist, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass der reparierte Bereich der optischen Faser (25) ein Ende (51) der optischen Faser (25), die in die Verbundstruktur (11) eingebettet ist, mit einem Ende (53) einer optischen Faser (55) verbindet, die sich außerhalb der Verbundstruktur (11) befindet.

A composite structure (11) comprising: a) a laminate structure formed by a plurality of layers (13, 15, 17, 19, 21, 23); b) an optical fiber (25) for structural monitoring purposes which is at least partly embedded in said laminate structure, the embedded part of the optical fiber (25) susceptible to requiring repair is integrated in a surface layer (13) of the laminate structure; and c) insulation means (31, 33, 27) located at the optical fiber areas susceptible to repair with respect to the surface layer (13) in which they are integrated; said insulation means (31, 33, 27) including: - a bottom separating film (33) positioned below the optical fiber (25) between the optical fiber (25) and the laminate structure so as to facilitate the separation of the optical fiber (25) from the laminate structure, - a top separating film (31) positioned on the optical fiber (25), and - a laminar protective cover (27) arranged on the top separating film (31).
A composite structure according to claim 1, characterized in that said protective cover (27) has dimensions slightly larger than those of the separating films (31, 33).
A composite structure according to claim 1 or 2, characterized in that said protective cover (27) is made of preimpregnated fiberglass fabric.
A composite structure according to claim 3, characterized in that all of the optical fiber (25) is embedded in a surface layer (13) of the structure (11).

A composite structure according to claim 3, characterized in that the part of the optical fiber (25) not embedded in the surface layer (13) of the structure (11) is embedded in the layer (15) adjacent to it or deeper.

A process of repairing the optical fiber embedded in a composite structure according to claims 6 or 7, characterized in that the repaired optical fiber (25) area connects ends (41, 43) of optical fiber (25) embedded in the composite structure.

A process of repairing the optical fiber embedded in a composite structure according to claims 6 or 7, characterized in that the repaired optical fiber (25) area connects one end (51) of optical fiber (25) embedded in the composite structure (11) with one end (53) of an optical fiber (55) located outside the composite structure (11).

Structure composite (11) comprenant : a) une structure stratifiée formée par une pluralité de couches (13, 15, 17, 19, 21, 23) ; b) une fibre optique (25) prévue à des fins de surveillance d'une structure, qui est incorporée au moins en partie dans ladite structure stratifiée, la partie incorporée de la fibre optique (25) susceptible de nécessiter une réparation étant intégrée dans une couche de surface (13) de la structure stratifiée ; et c) des moyens d'isolation (31, 33, 27) situés au niveau des zones de la fibre optique susceptibles à une réparation par rapport à la couche de surface (13) où ils sont intégrés ; lesdits moyens d'isolation (31, 33, 27) comprenant : - un film de séparation inférieur (33) positionné sous la fibre optique (25) entre la fibre optique (25) et la structure stratifiée de façon à faciliter la séparation de la fibre optique (25) de la structure stratifiée ; - un film de séparation supérieur (31) positionné sur la fibre optique (25) ; et - un couvercle de protection laminaire (27) agencé sur le film de séparation supérieur (31).
Structure composite selon la revendication 1, caractérisée en ce que ledit couvercle de protection (27) présente des dimensions légèrement plus grandes que celles des films de séparation (31, 33).
Structure composite selon la revendication 1 ou 2, caractérisée en ce que ledit couvercle de protection (27) est fabriqué d'un tissu de fibre de verre préimprégné.
Structure composite selon la revendication 3, caractérisée en ce que la totalité de la fibre optique (25) est incorporée dans une couche de surface (13) de la structure (11).

Structure composite selon la revendication 3, caractérisée en ce que la partie de la fibre optique (25) qui n'est pas incorporée dans la couche de surface (13) de la structure (11) est incorporée dans la couche (15) adjacente à celle-ci, ou plus profondément.

Procédé de réparation de la fibre optique (25) incorporée dans une structure composite selon la revendication 6 ou 7, caractérisé en ce que la zone de la fibre optique (25) réparée relie les extrémités (41, 43) de la fibre optique (25) incorporée dans la structure composite.

Procédé de réparation de la fibre optique (25) incorporée dans une structure composite selon la revendication 6 ou 7, caractérisé en ce que la zone de la fibre optique (25) réparée relie une extrémité (51) de la fibre optique (25) incorporée dans la structure composite (11), à une extrémité (53) d'une fibre optique (55) qui se situe à l'extérieur de la structure composite (11).
